products.name: Tamanu EMR
products.description: Open-source patient-level EMR for low-resource, remote healthcare settings. Covers outpatient, inpatient, emergency, laboratory, imaging, and pharmacy. Deployed across Pacific Island nations and humanitarian contexts. Desktop + mobile + sync architecture for offline-capable operation.
products.notes: Despite minimal ONC certification (only (b)(10) + privacy/security), the actual product has extensive clinical capabilities including FHIR APIs, immunization registries, NCD screening, lab/imaging integration, and an emerging patient portal. ONC certification appears strategic for international credibility rather than US market entry. Codebase is fully public on GitHub with ~100+ database models. Target market is Pacific Island national health systems and humanitarian healthcare (MSF), not US providers.

sources.note: Corporate homepage; company overview, B-Corp status, ~60+ staff, Melbourne HQ, Pacific Island focus
Product page (tamanu.io redirects here); comprehensive feature list, architecture, pricing, usage stats (14M+ encounters, 1.5M+ patients, 9 countries)
ONC mandatory disclosures; confirms minimal certification, free software + optional support pricing
Public monorepo; 18K+ commits, 139 contributors, GPL-3.0/BSL dual-licensed, active development (v2.48.0)
Database model directory; ~100+ model files revealing comprehensive data schema including clinical, pharmacy, lab, imaging, invoicing, portal, audit

notes: Australian B-Corp social enterprise, not a US-market vendor. Partners include World Bank, WHO, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, DFAT, UNFPA. Revenue from implementation services and support contracts ($165-$665/month/facility), not software licensing. Product is genuinely feature-rich and actively developed but serves global health/development sector. No G2 or KLAS listings. Open-source codebase enables definitive verification of data model against EHI export.
